plants.name: Camellia japonica
plants.description: A popular ornamental evergreen shrub native to eastern and southern Asia, known for its large, showy flowers that often bloom in winter to early spring, providing color in colder months.
plants.location: East Asia (Japan, China, Korea); widely cultivated in temperate regions worldwide
plants.funFact: Camellia japonica flowers were historically used to make tea before Camellia sinensis became popular.

plants.name: Crocus sativus
plants.description: A small perennial flowering plant famed for its crimson stigmas which are harvested as saffron spice. It blooms in late autumn to early winter and is cultivated in Mediterranean climates.
plants.funFact: Saffron crocus stigmas are the most expensive spice by weight due to labor-intensive harvesting.

plants.name: Helleborus niger
plants.description: A herbaceous perennial known for blooming in winter, often around Christmas and early January. Its waxy white flowers appear on leafless stems, brightening shady gardens.
plants.funFact: Despite its common name, the Christmas Rose is not related to true roses and is toxic if ingested.

plants.name: Banksia serrata
plants.description: An Australian native tree with large cylindrical flower spikes that appear mostly in winter and spring, attracting birds and mammals with nectar-rich flowers.
plants.bloomingSeason: May to January (peak bloom in Jan in some areas)
plants.funFact: Banksia flowers are made up of hundreds of tiny flowers packed together, creating the characteristic flower spikes.
